t: Proverbs 6
Dangerous Promises
My*pn son, if you become surety for your friend, If*ild you have shaken hands in pledge for a stranger,
You*ld are snared by the words of your mouth; You*ld are taken by the words of your mouth.
So*ld do this, my son, and deliver yourself; For*ld you have come into the hand of your friend: Go*ld and humble yourself; Plead*ld with your friend.
Give*ld no sleep to your eyes, Nor*ld slumber to your eyelids.
Deliver*ld yourself like a gazelle from the hand of*i the*i hunter,*i And*ld like a bird from the hand of the fowler.
The Folly of Indolence
Go*pn to the ant, you sluggard! Consider*ld her ways and be wise,
Which,*ld having no captain, Overseer*ld or ruler,
Provides*ld her supplies in the summer, And*ild gathers her food in the harvest.
How*ld long will you slumber, O sluggard? When*ld will you rise from your sleep?
A*ld little sleep, a little slumber, A*ld little folding of the hands to sleep—
So*ld shall your poverty come on you like a prowler, And*ld your need like an armed man.
The Wicked Man
A*pn worthless person, a wicked man, Walks*ld with a perverse mouth;
He*ld winks with his eyes, He*ld shuffles his feet, He*ld points with his fingers;
Perversity*ld is*i in his heart, He*ld devises evil continually, He*ld sows discord.
Therefore*ld his calamity shall come suddenly; Suddenly*ld he shall be broken without remedy.
These*ln six things*i the Lord*s hates, Yes,*ld seven are*i an abomination to Him:
A*ld proud look, A*ld lying tongue, Hands*ld that shed innocent blood,
A*ld heart that devises wicked plans, Feet*ld that are swift in running to evil,
A*ld false witness who*i speaks lies, And*ld one who sows discord among brethren.
Beware of Adultery
My*pn son, keep your father’s command, And*ld do not forsake the law of your mother.
Bind*ld them continually upon your heart; Tie*ld them around your neck.
When*ld you roam, they will lead you; When*ld you sleep, they will keep you; And*ld when*i you awake, they will speak with you.
For*ld the commandment is*i a lamp, And*ld the law a light; Reproofs*ld of instruction are*i the way of life,
To*ld keep you from the evil woman, From*ld the flattering tongue of a seductress.
Do*ld not lust after her beauty in your heart, Nor*ld let her allure you with her eyelids.
For*ld by means of a harlot A*ild man*i is*i reduced*i to a crust of bread; And*ld an adulteress will prey upon his precious life.
Can*ld a man take fire to his bosom, And*ld his clothes not be burned?
Can*ld one walk on hot coals, And*ld his feet not be seared?
So*ld is*i he who goes in to his neighbor’s wife; Whoever*ld touches her shall not be innocent.
People*iln do not despise a thief If*ld he steals to satisfy himself when he is starving.
Yet*ld when*i he is found, he must restore sevenfold; He*ld may have to give up all the substance of his house.
Whoever*ld commits adultery with a woman lacks understanding; He*ld who*i does so destroys his own soul.
Wounds*ld and dishonor he will get, And*ld his reproach will not be wiped away.
For*ld jealousy is*i a husband’s fury; Therefore*ld he will not spare in the day of vengeance.
He*ld will accept no recompense, Nor*ld will he be appeased though you give many gifts.
